Warhammer: End Times Vermintide This game makes the best use of the Warhammer license i have seen in a long time! I can see myself putting hours and hours into this game Lots too see Lots too do  9/10   Loss of a point due too the fact that it is still a tad badly optimized :)

The fun of Left 4 Dead 2 with juicy melee combat system. Rpg elements. Interesting fantasy setting set in the apocalypse of the Warhammer Fantasy world which ramps up the insanity to 110%. The potencial of this game is practicaly limitless. Grab your giant axe and whack some rats.

My rating: 7/10  You by now know that this game is L4D with a medieval fantasy flair--and that is LITERALLY what it is. In fact, it often feels more like a complete mod and reskin of L4D than it does an original game. This is not innately bad, however, but it does turn out kind of strange given the content.  In L4D, you were one of four 'normal' people trying to survive the zombie horde. It made sense when the sh*t hit the fan that you found it hard to survive. However, in Vermintide, you play as one of four 'skilled' heroes whose entire reason for being in the situation they find themselves is because they are the only ones with the skill and courage to defeat the rat hordes. There is no one else (save for the inn keeper, whose Inn is protected by magic, thankfully) left--everyone else is either dead or just simply gone. This plays out well enough, as most rats you can kill with one to two hits, as expected. However, it gets a little iffy (for me) when you have the uncommon rats show up.  The uncommon rats are akin to the uncommon zombies in L4D. In fact, all the attacks they do can be compared exactly to those in L4D. For example, the smoker and the Packmaster both grab you and drag you away from your party until your party interrupts him. While, again, not a bad thing, it's a little weird when you can't adequately defend against their special attacks, even though you are a stout and heavy dwarf carrying a giant hammer, or a mage with the ability to cast giant plumes of fire everywhere, and so on. The mechanics of these attacks on these types of characters in this kind of setting/genre doesn't seem to fit together and bothers me.  The game plays well enough, with only a few realtively minor issues along the way. These included locking up my computer the first time I loaded the game and a strange issue where my game would appear to freeze whenever I stepped into a very specific spot. Both issues have only occured once each, and the former may not even be the game's fault. Other issues are small annoyances like glitching rats which cheapens some hits on you, and the like. Otherwise, the game has played smoothly, even at extreme settings (it auto selected High settings for me).  One major feature that is nice is the loot system, which will be one of the main reasons you keep playing for hours. Common loot appears to be given after each personal level you obtain. After each map level that you COMPLETE, you roll dice for a chance to get loot. The more dice sides you get, the better loot you get. You can get 'better' dice if players pick up tomes and special dice during the map level and finish with them in their possession. However, don't expect these items to give you too much more of an advantage as I've seen all but one special dice still come up with only one good side, granting me only common loot. That said, the weapons appear to be varied enough to be able to pick some favorites as you collect loot.  In the end, I'd only recommend this game to anyone that likes L4D mechanics, but wants it all in a fantasy setting. If you didn't like L4D, you will not like this game.

As a fan of Warhammer franchise for over 15 years I was excited the first moment I heard: Warhammer co-op game, L4D/PD2 lookalike. Yes! Great idea! Knowing the previously mentioned games, liking them for being really addictive and enjoyable, I couldn't imagine, how Vermintide could be bad. Well, it could. It is, really.  You can't say that graphics or music is bad, these are ok. Nothing really outstanding, but audio-visual aspects are simply right. The end.   The main part of the game, the thing, that should push it, the water for the watermill, the fuel for the engine, the air for the living creatures, should be the mechanics. That aspect sucks. Why? Here comes why: - Linearity to the limits of boredom - Fighting system simple to the point of boredom - Characters levelling - pointless, because you really gain almost nothing with every level. Boring - Replayability doesn't exist. Because missions are simply boring. - Characters differences? Almost none. There was no big difference playing as witch hunter or waywatcher - felt so similar. Boring. - Customisation? What customisation? - Weapon modding? Weapon collecting? All praise the RNG-sus, as this is the way to go. - Equipment choice? Ridiculously small. I don't write about initial choice, I write about the general: you are limited to just a few weapons, that can be only slightly improved. Randomly.  Generally it is ridiculously poorly executed opportunity. There was such a great potential. The possibilities were endless: - Creating you own hero with some skill/class system, at least bigger differences between preset heroes! Something like support classes with healing and differences in gameplay as tank or agile fighter. Faster and slower ones. Tougher and weaker.  - The forge - weapon creating system that could give you some room to experiment. Maybe secret recipes to find in game or as a reward for achievements. The forge here is just disappointing. - More possibilities of ending the level - the choice of strategy, maybe different ways of going to the goal. - More open locations, less linear, some environment features to be more tactical.  - More equipment - armor sets, more slots for collectibles, med supplies, but as well tougher enemies (inflicting more damage), what would make the game more demanding.  - More appealing system of rewards - something, that would attracts you more. Gives you new possibilities to explore. Now the only reward is some weapon - great chance, that it is something you are not interested in. Even if you do, upgrading your equipment is, as everything, random. It's ridiculous!  Well, long story short: a big letdown. The game is just boring. Absolutely wasted potential.  P.S. There is a possibility, that there will be a lot of features in the future, in paid DLCs. It would be cheap and disgusting trick, because the basic game is just too poor, too simple, underdeveloped. Paying for such add-ons would be like paying for the base game, but part after part for years... In that exact moment it feels, like you are playing early beta.

My rating: 7/10  You by now know that this game is L4D with a medieval fantasy flair--and that is LITERALLY what it is. In fact, it often feels more like a complete mod and reskin of L4D than it does an original game. This is not innately bad, however, but it does turn out kind of strange given the content.  In L4D, you were one of four 'normal' people trying to survive the zombie horde. It made sense when the sh*t hit the fan that you found it hard to survive. However, in Vermintide, you play as one of four 'skilled' heroes whose entire reason for being in the situation they find themselves is because they are the only ones with the skill and courage to defeat the rat hordes. There is no one else (save for the inn keeper, whose Inn is protected by magic, thankfully) left--everyone else is either dead or just simply gone. This plays out well enough, as most rats you can kill with one to two hits, as expected. However, it gets a little iffy (for me) when you have the uncommon rats show up.  The uncommon rats are akin to the uncommon zombies in L4D. In fact, all the attacks they do can be compared exactly to those in L4D. For example, the smoker and the Packmaster both grab you and drag you away from your party until your party interrupts him. While, again, not a bad thing, it's a little weird when you can't adequately defend against their special attacks, even though you are a stout and heavy dwarf carrying a giant hammer, or a mage with the ability to cast giant plumes of fire everywhere, and so on. The mechanics of these attacks on these types of characters in this kind of setting/genre doesn't seem to fit together and bothers me.  The game plays well enough, with only a few realtively minor issues along the way. These included locking up my computer the first time I loaded the game and a strange issue where my game would appear to freeze whenever I stepped into a very specific spot. Both issues have only occured once each, and the former may not even be the game's fault. Other issues are small annoyances like glitching rats which cheapens some hits on you, and the like. Otherwise, the game has played smoothly, even at extreme settings (it auto selected High settings for me).  One major feature that is nice is the loot system, which will be one of the main reasons you keep playing for hours. Common loot appears to be given after each personal level you obtain. After each map level that you COMPLETE, you roll dice for a chance to get loot. The more dice sides you get, the better loot you get. You can get 'better' dice if players pick up tomes and special dice during the map level and finish with them in their possession. However, don't expect these items to give you too much more of an advantage as I've seen all but one special dice still come up with only one good side, granting me only common loot. That said, the weapons appear to be varied enough to be able to pick some favorites as you collect loot.  In the end, I'd only recommend this game to anyone that likes L4D mechanics, but wants it all in a fantasy setting. If you didn't like L4D, you will not like this game.

Played free weekend.  About 10 hours played and i have to say. this game is dull as crap with no actual abilities or skills to use.  the weapons are your only loot which are almost all the same except for a minor 'passive' that triggers rarely. a proc of 1~3% chance on a charged attack to heal for 5 hit points.... 15% faster firing rate on a bow. 30~50% chance your stamina refills once depleted...  What i mean to say is that there is litterly nothing FUN about the combat. you constantly spam leftclick or occasionally pull out a range weapon to hit something far of. no abilities to speak of like in diablo or any other horde beater. simply said its very uninspired and thats saying for a Warhammer game.  so far i have managed to beat the entire main campaign which is about 10 diferent maps.  collect barrels, collect grain, destroy something or defend something. those are the only missions you really have. most of the time you have to walk to this location before the mission actually starts but its quite liniair with no multiple routes to take.  enemies so far i encountered counts to 8 enemies that you fight. -the Gutter runner (an assassin) jumps ontop of you to pin ya to the ground and stabs ya till your dead. this bugger is really fast. -the gunner rat. uses a machine gun that shoots like a mofo on steroids. since he has heavy armor your only bet is to beat him with charging attacks (hold left mouse button) or have a stupidly powerful ranged weapon that 1 shots every enemy in the game Except the rat Ogre. -the Stormvermin are heavy armored melee soldies that often appear in packs as a sort of patrol that are a chore to beat. but with a trueflight bow or a rifle you 1 hit them all. making these really nothing to be scared about. -the Poison tosser dude (i forget their names) tosses. vials of poison to damage you and your enemies. often he clears out the trash for you so ya can chop its head off. i thought all skaven were immune to poison. what gives? -The rat ogre. this is your typical brute which takes a ♥♥♥♥load to take down even with strong bows and rifles. chop chop at it till its dead but if your targeted run like crazy. -packleader this enemy often grabs ya like some kidnapper and drags ya away till your dead as ♥♥♥♥. these often appear in between packs of trash so they are hard to chase down since there is No sprint option in the game. -trashpacks. there are 2 typs of trash rats. small ones that die in 1 hit. and medium ones that die in 1 hit..... these are your typical swarm enemies and are boring as ♥♥♥♥ since you hear them comming by the sound of a loud ♥♥♥ horn blowing.  since there are 5 characters doing pretty much the same ♥♥♥♥ each the game feels boring as crap. the loot is randomized and so you can get gear for a character you do not want to use.  if ya use all characters, then yeah its eventually usefull.  overall this free weekend showed me that i should bother buying the game. i played with my brother and beated the whole main thing but man was it lame. with no abilities your just swinging your weapons like a loony and with no awesome loot that changes your playstyle you quickly get attached to what your fav set is. specially when you only obtain 1 item per run which takes about 30minutes to an hour and god forbid if you lose! even then its litterly by the roll of the dice if ya get something.  i suggest avoiding this game. L4D2 did this a ton times better the only thing this game has going for it is the warhammer theme... and even that they slacked on.. seriously guys. no warrior priest? atleast let us costumize the character we are using!  if ya want a cool warhammer game i suggest Mordheim!

The game's major problem is it's repetivness and the unrewarding loot. You get 1 chance for an item every won game, so one item roughly every 30 minutes that may not even be of use because it is for a character you don't enjoy playing. Also, broken down in logic, you have to beat hard difficulties to get rare gear, which you need to beat those hard difficulties. You can also craft gear, but even at the second difficulty only material for white Items drops. Andvancing your gear still requires luck or grind with winning rewards.  Gave it a second chance and played it with friends, we all felt the same way.

Have you ever wonder why Charlie Kelly loves killing rats so much? This game explains it.  Solid chunky combat, different weapons completely alter your attack strategy. Some bugs, but I haven't come across anything major or that has hurt my enjoyment of the game.  Sadly, just like L4D, their is an elitest community starting to form, but make some friends and play with them.

Pros: +Skaven +Specials +Multiplayer +Interesting game  Cons: -Neverending hordes -Virtually impossible to finish missions on any difficulty higher than normal -Spears that take a 1/3rd of your health -A loot system that is so ridiculous horrible, you're very unlikely to ever get anything useful -A crafting system that is so weird, you'll wonder why it's even worth using -So much luck-based content, that you're going to rip your eyes out -The AI Director. HATES. YOU. WITH. A. PASSION. -Virtually no limit on special skaven; closest comparison? L4D2: 3 boomers, 2 hunters, 4 spitters, 2 tanks -You're rarely ever going to get the talents you want on your items -Unless you can somehow see 360 degrees around you, you're going to die on any difficulty  Notes: I love Warhammer. I love Skaven. But, this? This game makes me want to rip my eyes out and eat them. I cannot tell you how many times I lost, just because of how many specials there were at one moment. The crafting is extremely luck-based, you're going to be wondering when you'll get what you really wanted. I do like this game, it's creative, it's fun- when the glorious AI Director doesn't smite you down with 3 gatling gunners, 2 globadiers, a gutter runner and a rat ogre.  Devs. Please. Fix this game, and I will give you my undying love.

Don't buy please save money go buy this on sale for 50% off or on ♥♥♥♥♥ this game has very little to offer i loved it when i first got it but that was very very short lived. Dont buy it until more is added in for free dont bother if dlc is not free

Challenging, requires teamwork, L4D style game with swords, Warhammer End Times, all great things.  It can get repetitive, as there are only limited maps. But as the enemy spawns are random and you never play the map the same way twice because of it.

Love the game. Lots of content and replayability, havent been this addicted to a game in ages, so much so that i decided to write my first review to support it. buy it.    Only problem is some frame rate drops here and there, which should be sorted in time to come with driver updates.

I am giving this game a negative review only due to the developers complete lack of fixing game breaking bugs.  I cannot progress in the game due to 2 major crashes that appear to be common for everyone.  first is a straight forward crash to desk top and the second is a super speed issue, everything goes into super speed and the game cant be played, you die in seconds when this happens, one of these happen at least once every 2 games i set or join, i have a system capable of running much better that what this game can give, so i know this is not the problem.  these 2 crash issues have been happening for the last few months, they have been acknowledged by the developers but nothing has been done.  The loot system is terrible, at the end of each game you roll a number of dice, the more you score the better your loot, however if you think you have a chance for rolling to get the top items, good luck, never happens.  The game is very short but has decent replayability.  The gameplay is actually very good.  very smooth and looks fantastic with everything maxed in detail.  very satisfying fighting style.  the game does have single player, but in reality this is pointless unless your happy to stay with the green or blue quality loot.  If you can get the game on a very high discount, then its worth it, but at full price, save your money and get something else, at least for now.

Feels similar to L4D2 with some classic item collection, and a slight rpg feel due to the weapons and forge that allows you to combine 5 items of the same tier to a higher one, or fuse the weapon with gems/stones to unlock their traits. You could definately play this for hundreds of hours like certain other games, and not get bored cause of how the enemies act and of course the different levels of difficulty.   It feels focused mainly around the melee combat with range being more of a secondary type thing meant for moments where you actually need it. (specials, rat ogres.) The visuals are pretty good despite myself playing on low/medium. The optimization could be better, but that's about one of the only things that stands out in my mind that could be better besides small little things which are more of my own opinion than in any need of attention.  Like; Their has yet to be any varying combinations in melee combat that I can see besides the standard one that comes with the weapon, hopefully that will be built upon where you have more choices of which direction you swing, and different combinations. That's neither here nore there though.  The controls all work fluently except for jumping imo cause it can be abit picky with the enviromental collision. I enjoyed the voice acting, and the animations are great for how they receive blows, and different ways the skaven die.    I'd rate this game a 4/5 mostly because I think the combat mechanics could be abit more immersive with having directional attacks whether it be by moving or mouse (Think Mount & Blade Warband) Other than that, it's really fun game, and I'd recommend this game to my friends.

GW does such a great job at attracting their target audience with their games. The flavor of the end of times is disgustingly dripping from this game. If you liked L4D2 and have some spare money to throw at a similar experience, you can't go wrong here.

I wasn't really sure if I should vote thumbs up or thumbs down on this... So I went with positive. Why? Well hang out for a sec and I'll explain.   What is Vermintide?  Well it's basically a rip off of a few different games but mostly a rip off of Left 4 Dead, but... It's a rip off done right.  In Vermintide you can chose from one of five different characters, you level up but this seems to have no real effect on your toon besides unlocking slots to equip trinkets that have zero effect in game... You can loot, and craft, kind of. You get loot at the end of a round if you complete the round, if not you just get xp. So a slight rpg mechanic is in place thought the results of leveling up are unsatasfying because you don't really gain anything.  Crafting is designed to take a fair amount of materials to make anything good, which keeps you farming, er I mean playing.  The combat is Mele, and well. They got it right, in fact it's the best FPS style game that has been able to nail down combat with a swung weapon. Sure L4D2 tried, but they failed miserably at it. In Vermintide it just feels right, the distances, the reaction times, how I don't feel like I have to get so close to something that I've almost walked past it in order to strike it where it seems the enemies could strike me from almost out of site. That's right, none of that. It's balanced in the reach and you can actually block, push, and attack effectively. More good, It's Hard.  Why is that good? Because it actually presents a challenge and all team members must not only stay together but work together and have some skills to survive.  The playable toons are different, not only in looks and animation but different skill sets, and abilities.  So how is this a Left 4 Dead rip off you might ask? Well the special mobs. All do basically what the L4D mobs do. You have a tank/oger, Jocky/Task master, boomer, smoker hybrid being a /glober in this game tossing smoke bombs then charging at you to explode if it's near death, hunter/gut runner, The waves of enemies come in as hords, and they have patrols which are arguably different but it's basically a random mechanic designed to take you out or cause you greef if you get slopy, much the way the car alarms are in L4D.   That being said, this re-skinned Left 4 Dead game with a few inventive twists is fun to play, it's challenging, and can even be a little aggrivating if you are matched up with people who don't get the idea of working together. The enviornents are fantastic, the animations are great, the game play is fun, and really what more do you want.  The game does have some opt issues and drops frames once and a while, usually just before an 'event' which can ruin the suprise... and no, it's not my computer. Check my specs on my page and or note that I can run the Witcher 3 on this thing at 4k with no issues.   So what's the verdict? Would I recomend buying it or not? That's a hard one, it's a good game and fun, but it seems like Valve diserves the money for the blatent plagerism commited by this game more than that dev's deserve the money for only half ♥♥♥ optimizing it. I bought it, I play it.. so figured that would be the tipping point in giving it a positive review.

It's Left 4 Dead but with persistent progress, loot to keep you running, and meaningful class distinctions. Excellent level of challenge- any difficulty above Normal (and even Normal sometiems) requires tight cooperation and effort, but is not unbeatable with effort and teamwork.  The game also boasts satisfying hit animations for various contact locations on enemies, and the best first person melee combat I've ever seen. As a co-op junkie this is easily one of my all time favorites. It takes a little while to warm up to them, but once you do the cast of characters is one of this game's strongest pulls; their banter and comments in levels are always entertaining and interesting. Progress of updates is a bit slow but steady, and updates are generally of high quality and significance to the game.  Be wary of high RNG in loot drops (that's just how it is, especially when you are starting off and don't have the resources to use some of the later-added systems that give you more control), below-average optimization (don't expect 60fps if you aren't on a very high end system, but most people should have no problem with 30+), and occasional jankiness in certain areas (invisible walls, imperfect collision on certain rocks, etc).   All in all, it's probably my favorite game of 2015, and one of my favorite co-op experiences of all time. Highly recommended to anyone who likes co-operative games, Warhammer in general (maybe the best use of the Warhammer license in a videogame), or anyone looking for satisfying first person melee combat.

Bias warning: I am a Warhammer -fanboy and love the Skaven above all.  Vermintide is fun!  The game tells the tale of a Skaven (rat-man) invasion of the city of Ubersreik, with ratmen swarming from the sewers, spilling into the streets, overwhelming the city guard and resulting in a desperate band of survivors struggling to hold their own and to strike back at the rats.  Much of Vermintide can be simplified to 'Left4Dead with less guns and more swords', but there is more to it than that. Some of the unique rats that take the place of special infected, such as the ratling gunner and especially the packmaster make for some really exciting encounters, with a pair of packmasters able to easily wipe out an entire team of careless players. The varied weapons, shields and abilities of the five playable characters change up the style of play, with the fire mage standing out as the most unique of them all. Each character is well-written and full of personality, which is conveyed in their chatter throughout the game. I especially grew to love the witch hunters glum look on the world as I played.  With all the difficulty settings, missions, last stands and such, Vermintide offers a ton of replayability and fun. I do have to warn you, though: the friendly AI is not much good. It has a tendency to wander off and fall into pits and die.   Playtime: 16+ hours (Multiplayer only)  Ratings (1-10) Visual: 8 Audio: 9 Story: 10 Gameplay: 7 Overall: 9

8/10  Good game, good fun, very addictive but I personally have had a bit of bad experience in actually getting a game, I've found myself waiting in matchmaking for so long that I am set to host which is fine but then I'm stuck in matchmaking as host for far too long and decide to hell with it I'll play by myself with the BOTS...some of the worst AI ever, same as with left for dead but more frustrating in this instance as I enjoy this game a lot and am a huge warhammer fan. But I suppose that's to be expected, the game is developed as a multiplayer game with teamwork in mind. Other than that one little problem the game is a lot of fun when playing with a team of non BOT players, it's a lot of fun to work in a tactically organised way, or at least try to, and the pressure of being overwhelmed by the enemy is great. reviving is also quicker than with past experiences in similar games. On that note I do recomend that you don't try to be a lone wolf, stick with your team, help them if they are in trouble. this is one of those games where if you are good to your team mates they'll be good to you and the reward for sticking together is far greater than trying to go it alone.

A lot of rats, a lot of bugs, a lot of fun.  As with any coop games, Vermintide's fun mostly relies on how good your brother in arms are. If you have a team of 4 friends ready to slaughter thousands of skaven, then you're in for a treat. If like me you're mostly planning on matchmaking, then the fun is a bit more random, and made even more random by recurring bugs which can disconnect you in the middle of a mission for example.  It'll take you about 6-7 hours to do all missions in normal difficulty. After that, you're welcome to try out harder modes, and if you're a loot addict you can do the missions over and over again for better gear.  Overall quite recommended despite its flaws. Here's to hoping the success of the game will lead the developers to support it over a long time !

Pretty fun co-op action game. If you feel like you've played it before, you've probably played Left 4 Dead. While it does borrow several elements from L4D (four player co-op, fending off waves of a horde (rats), special buff monsters (see tank rat), objective based scenarios), it does manage to change up the formula a bit. The biggest difference is its focus on melee combat, which is executed fairly well. Swinging a weapon into an enemy manages to feel satisfyingly visceral, not unlike something you'd experience in Chivalry. There are still ranged weapons, but they are definitely downplayed in comparison. Other differences include class based characters, each with their own set of unique weapons, as well as some minor RPG-inspired mechanics. These are mostly restricted to loot-based weapon quality upgrades and upgradable weapon traits (a chance to heal on hit, for example), however they bring some welcome customizability to the game.  Overall, Vermintide is a pretty good co-op experience. The RNG for loot can be annoying, it's supposed to encourage you to try multiple classes, but if you like to stick to a class like me you'll feel cheated by it a lot, as it dumps gear for mostly other classes on you. It's a relatively minor annoyance though, all things considered, and the game is definitely still winnable without the highest tier loot. Definitely recommended if you are looking for a slightly more difficult and varied Left 4 Dead experience.

This game is a lot of fun, and has really strong replay value to it. I dont understand the complaints of unit balance, each character is unique and has definite strengths and weaknesses as is with most other Warhammer-branded games.  But the packmasters. They need to be changed. Having your ENTIRE party systematically grabbed, hoisted up and left to die by a single rat is ridiculous. The AI doesn't seem to notice when it happens either if you are playing with bots, and will also get grabbed in similar fashion, or stand there and watch. Having absolutely no way to fight it doesn't make sense if the bots are going to ignore you until they get grabbed too. Also, the only thing special about the rat is that it has the polearm to snag you with, so I dont quite understand how shooting it mercilessly in the chest/face doesn't kill it, especially considering other similarly armored rats go down in 1-2 hits tops. Don't bother trying to swing at it - it's range is also stupid long, he will grab you long before you get anywhere near hitting him, even with a 2-handed sword that otherwise has fantastic range.  Too angry at the game right now to write much else, I love playing and really have no other gripes, but this one aspect is getting so annoying that it is making me question whether I want to keep playing or not.

9/10  The funnest game I've played in a long time. Vermintide is a very challenging, heavy team-reliance game. And part of the fun is learning how to handle extreme hordes of rats plummeting on you and swarming at you and your team with the wide selection of weapons and classes that are available. The game shares some qualities from the L4D franchise and I would say it is primarily melee combat.  Difficulty levels are choosable from easy, medium, hard, nightmare, and cataclysmic...and they are indeed what the names suggest. Be prepared to have your jimmies rustled at times.   There is a cool forging system for upgrading and modifying your weapon arsenal. After awhile you will get a lot of weapon drops and can use the forge.  I am overlooking the fact that the game has [some] serious optimization problems and a few bugs despite being released officially. And this is only due to the fact that I have so much fun playing.  Cons:  -Game optimization is still in the works(from what I've seen the devs are very resposive and keep the updates coming).  -AI is not the smartest, so don't plan on beating maps without real players beyond hard difficulty. That means singleplayer is limited at this current time. -There is some toxicity in the playerbase, not too bad, but it's bound to exist in games that give a lot of freedom to players.  Tips: -You must enable VOIP in settings in order to hear or use voice chat. -At the moment the average person has tweaked their settings to about Medium in order to have decent FPS. Mess around until it's to your liking, the optimization will improve- trust in the devs! -Friendly fire is enabled in Nightmare and Cataclysm mode, and applies only to range hits and bomb explosions. Yes there are bombs!   The game is good. Have fun!

Vermintide is a slightly better Left 4 Dead Co-Op. If you enjoyed Left 4 Dead Co-Op, you will enjoy Vermintide.  Vermintide is about co-op, but it is frustrating co-op. You may get randomly knocked off a cliff or edge, and your teammates will have to come pick you up. You may get pounced by a special infecte... *cough* 'stabrat', and your companions will have to help you. At all times, you may be subjected to a situation that takes away all control and forces your teammates to aid you. This is both a pro and a con.  If you have a regular group to play with, Vermintide is at it's best, but even then it is insanely grindy. Even if you do a perfect run, the end result is completely random (as in actually represented by dice). You can play the perfect game and get complete trash. Playing a bad (losing) game, however, gets you nothing. Playing through a 30-40 minute mission for another common melee weapon for a class you don't play gets tiresome.  But Vermintide has lots of potential. Whether or not that potential is realized in patch notes or DLC will determine whether or not I manage to keep my interest in this game. As it stands, Vermintide is a decent co-op title, and can be fun for 1-3 missions for an evening with your friends. I got about 20 hours in this game, and I'm nowhere near the top tier when it comes to items (because of the batshit crazy grinding). I guess they implemented this because their loot system was so shallow, and they wanted it to take their players a long time to max out.  Buy this game if you have lots of friends and a sale comes up. Play for a weekend or two. I'd recommend it if it drops to a 15-20€ price range.

A fun L4D clone thats a good purchase when its on sale.  Got it for 50% off and 3 of us have been enjoying ourselves. The inventory/looting system is a nice touch. The loot system itself is frustrating but not because the rewards are RNG, but more because extra effort still has a chance to net you no gain. For example today we beat a level and managed to put the extra work into taking all 3 tombs with us to the end. No one in our group got anything beyond a 'grey' regular reward, despite having the highest amount of dice we've had to date. Im not huge on RNG loot, but i could live with it if recovering all 3 tombs guarnteed a minimum standard of loot (even green quality would be enough). Just as this point we feel we might not go out of our way for the tombs again.   As for people complaining about the bugs, we havent seen any beyond a couple invisible scaven that we still managed to kill by swinging at the air. lol. Everything else is crap you would of seen in L4D (odd clipping issues, etc)  Anyhow, in summary, enjoyable game if you have friends and you get it on sale, probably an easy 20-60 hours of game time here.

Its a interesting and fun game to play but for the price of 27,99 euro,it offers way to little.Took me 4 hours to play throught all the non DLC(witch are 3 more) missions on normal difficulty and to play them all again but at the hardest its probably going to take me 4 more hours.Beyond that there isnt that much you can do in order to not get borred and forget about the game. The game has/had a lot of potential but for a year after its release it still doesn offer what it should. -Very few game modes and even less maps to play at. -The game is a co-operative type yet you can do the missions with no teamwork whats so ever unless every body runs 30m away from each other. -Bugs that should be fixed at day 1 like the moment when you join a match and you insantly get killed by the npcs. -The 'Unique Heroes' in the game feel the same:first weapon a mele type(your going to use that 90% of the time) and the second a ranged type with very limmeted ammo(unless your with the wizard). -'Battle Unpredictable Enemies' - Every time you play a mission the enemys are going to be at the same places as before and attack you the same way.The moments with the boss like units are the same every time and happen on the same place as before. -'Experience an Immersive Story' - It has a good story but its anyting but immersive. -Even at easy difficulty at moments enemys just swarm you and then its game over. Overall i liked the time spent at the 'free weekend time' but for me this is a game thats going to interesting for the first 20 hours,after that i wont look it at all.

Great fun, despite its shortcomings, particularly the small amount of playable content.  The DLCs have done next to nothing to remedy the issue and all of the post-launch content is either practically broken (Last Stand) or sub-par production (Castle Drachenfels with its recycled geometry and dragged-out add fights), and of course costs you far more than content that's in the game at launch.  The core game missions are still great and I find the Fantasy Co-op gameplay and immersion really enjoyable, so I'm giving my recommendation for the game if you can get it with a discount.

Warhammer: The End-  It's called Vermintide. Vermintide.  Anyway...it's a co-op action game strictly in the vein of Left 4 Dead, though with plenty of robust ideas of its own.  The Warhammer setting (not usually my thing but brought to wonderfully twisted life here) makes for a rich and different take on the co-op experience with two major changes.  Firstly and the most obvious, is that instead of fighting hordes of the undead yet again, Vermintide pits you against the Skaven, hordes of fiendish ratmen who can wield weapons, climb over anything and come at you in droves. Naturally there are a few special types to add challenge and surprise, capable of ambushing cocky team members but they come in some unique, characterful flavours. They are a constant challenge and always fun to fight.  The second major difference is the cast of characters, who essentially fall into five distinct classes, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. In a rather pleasant change of design though, no character is too distinct from another and it's quite easy to tailor each one to your playstyle. You do end up with favourites but landing in a game as a character who's not your preference doesn't bring an end to your fun and I often find it quite fun to shake things up as a different character.  There's also a simple but robust loot system that adds some additional longevity on top of simply mastering the games base challenges by setting you in pursuit of better and more unique weapons. This also encourages players to seek out optional objectives like tomes scattered round each level which can be gathered and brought to the end of a mission for bonus loot.  Overall, Vermintide proves that whilst it adheres to a pre-existing template, it isn't afraid to bring its own character to the proceedings and inject some new life into the co-op design. It's a smart, challenging and incredibly fun game dripping with atmosphere and surprise. Great co-op games seem a rarity these days but for those seeking their fill, Vermintide may be one of the very best in a good long while.

Even though I'm not recommending this, I'm going to say it's a very good game and worth keeping your eye on. The only reasons I don't is because it has three big problems, and that is that the servers are client based and there is no host migration at the moment. This means that if you go through an entire mission and at the last moment, even after completing the mission you disconnect from host, then you don't get any reward for that mission and loose all progress. The other major problem is the loot system needs some serious work, it's way too RNG at the moment. I think they could really learn from games like Payday on how to make a decent weapon system that involves drops but doesn't just frustrate the player base. Both of these things they have said they are working on, and when they fix it I'll definitely change this to a recommend. The last is that the specials in this game are highly unbalanced and even buggy, you'll get shot at and grabbed through walls, as well as just end up facing an impossible number of them at a single time. They need some serious balancing and bug fixing.  As far as the game goes, it's a very good game. The graphics are pretty good, which as a side warning the game takes up a lot of resources and it's not just poor optimization but also just the fact that they didn't really compromise the graphics to account for the high quantity of things to render (hordes of rats and all). I'm playing on a 970 SSC and getting decent high quality settings. The gameplay is very similar to the L4D series and if you enjoy a co-op game you'll have fun here. Sure, the community isn't always the best but I don't think it's the worst I've been a part of. Mostly if you stick to easy and normal games for your first 10ish levels you should be fine.

I hated this piece of trash. The fact that it rates a 'C,' that's a hard 70-80% approval, only tells me how attrocious the current list of available titles truly is. The games industry seriously needs an ♥♥♥♥♥, and it can start with this game. I think I would've hated it less, maybe, if it had not been touted as a fantasy L4D2-like. Nothing about these characters makes them anything more than stereotypical fantasy fodder. No personality. Completely 2-dimensional. Also, unlike L4D2, the weapons and enemies feel non-existant. The swings don't connect properly--or didn't in the free trial I played. There is no proper sense of weight to build reality. The enemies fly and flop and really don't feel satisfying because it just lacks the basic feeling of a good, solid, connection during combat the way the best games deliver. Add to it that you're just hopping from server/room/instance to server/room/instance to join random groups of strangers in completely mind-numbing repetition of kill, kill, kill, and you get the point. This game is a valiant, if failed, attempt at the direction that many of these titles need to go--emulate the best, innovate the rest. BUT it fails. Hard. I can't recommend you spend one micron of your life on this game, but your time is yours to waste. Personally, I'd rather have a lobotomy than play this again.

Played around 60 hours and I'm kinda done with it. It has fun elements and grinding for loot (if that is your thing) is cool. It has a very basic crafting system, but enough to keep you going.  The biggest thing I have against this game, is the other players. There are a lot of decent/good players, but also a lot of bad ones. Level 10 players (new players) who think joining a game on hard or higher is a good idea. These people mess your game up. Since you get next to nothing if a mission fails and a mission can take up to 20 minutes, this is really bad.  The game doesn't have a kick/ban option for the host, you need to vote. Voteban isn't even an option too. A simple solution would be to be able to set a minimum gear requirement on your own created sessions, to prevent the noobs from joining.  I recommend this game if you: -LIke to grind the same levels over and over (get the DLCs for more options) to get the perfec gear for all the characters. -Don't mind to waste 20+ minutes because some people are real noob.

I tried.... I tried to like / recomment this game, but I simply can't. Every thing seemed to fit. Warhammer, Coop, Loot...But the systems just aren't well interegrated, so you have a randomized senseless grind, but why?  The Loot part would be so nice, if it was guaranteed. You can be the best player of the team, carry it, be supportive and hint at all tomes and grims, but if you roll bad, it's just a white item for you. And if new players just ignore the hints you have no tomes or grims and everyone gets worses loot. Is it so hard to give good players a bonus die or pity loot if yust the last event fails with all bonus objectives? No. But one mistake by one player is often a death penalty for the whole group. Random players below ~30-50 are clueless and fail to follow even the most simple orders. Map fails, repeat, more grind. Even WITH the Sigmars blessing update you may get loot for your preferred character, but again, it is not guaranteed and you need alot items to get your wanted item stats. More grind. The grind wouldn't be so bad if the game was more enjoyable. Players don't have a good way to communicate better and you often have 4 Single players (chat is ignored and voice is disabled by most players apparently), big events are mostly done by using glitches and/or players with way better gear, enemies are mostly hordes who are able to clip inside each other, so you hit one rat or more, depending on weapon, but get hit by 5 rats clipping inside 1. Fun. Finishing a match without tomes and grimoires is basically a waste of time thanks to the low chances at the loot for dice rolls system, compared to the effort and as mentioned before only like 50% of players pay attention to them and even less are able to finish with them.  Only get this game IF you like Warhammer very much, are prepared to grind a lot AND have a group of 4 players who you can enjoy it with, otherwise the experience may differ greatly.

Though the game is quite nice to behold, the companion State Machine (it's not even close to being what I would consider for “modern games AI”) is clearly incompetent; often breaking down or working in a highly counter intuitive fashion. I'll admit that as I write this, I'm fairly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off! However in barely 6 games (I.e. the first six I played,) I had more reasons to complain about the companion’s behaviour than I have for the entirety of the time I have played any other game with similar mechanics. I have played closer to 30 now & still haven’t managed to actually complete a mission due to the SM bugs  I write this the day before this title releases & honestly I hope this title has one hell of a day one patch coming; as is, the delivery of the single player experience is crippled, leaving a greatly underwhelming experience once frustration sets in. As for MP, I would only recommend it if you have friends who both like GW products and were already planning to purchase the title.  And for those who want to tout the Public card; screw that noise, pub is what makes playing with bots appealing.  If the State Machine is improved to an acceptable level, I would happily change this review to “Recommended”. This game, based on what it has outside of my concerns, is easily game of the year material (again that might be bias on my part as a Fantasy & 40K player.) Now that I've ranted, I just feel depressed, so I'm off to take some meds.  Addendum ----  To my eye it appears that the bots run on the Boolean combat switch; which means when they deem they are “in combat”, they won’t: • heal themselves. • heal teammates. • revive fallen teammates.  • disengage from combat.  • ignore enemies that they can’t get to or at. • think it’s a bad idea to melee charge a Rat Ogre while they are bleeding out.  Some of the situations that tend to occur. (I would do scenario examples but it would just come off as more bitter)  Often Bots: 1. don’t act independently. (As in they zombie swarm every task, also this may apply to the following entries) 2. stop moving entirely. (May be related to combat switch, nee path finding) 3. stare wistfully at enemies out of melee range without switch to their ranged weapons. (Killing the enemy yourself seems to get them moving again) 4. won’t wait for a gas cloud to dissipate if a comrade is downed inside.     Sometimes Bots: 1. blunder in front of you as you’re lining up a shot. (Luckily FF and FF Collision is off) 2. run away from you (or huddle together,) when you equip the med pack.  3. talk down at you with info blurb. (Bit of a pet peeve) 4. ignore that they actually have ranged weapons and charge across large areas. 5. will ditch a pitched battle to run back across the map, to hunt down a miss spawned “Special” 6. use their med kit on a badly injured teammate, sometimes even when they are bleeding out.

I am very disappointed by the lack of actual content. This game can be 'beaten' in less than 12 hours. Although all missions can be replayed at higher difficulty; the levels, characters, and enemies are too unimaginative to provide any real incentive to do so. This is a respectable attempt at recreating the L4D playstyle, but it falls flat in all the little places in between gameplay.  I might have picked this game back up, but the release of a paid DLC feels like a slap, or at the very least it shows where the developers intend to focus. It smacks of quick release with little content to maximize profit in a game they have clearly abandoned.

As if I didn't hate rats enough.  So I played it for the free weekend, had fun, it was interesting. But while a fun game that saw L4D's style and said, 'You know, that works. That looks fun. Let's see if we can do something similar.' it feels wanting, as if it's good, but it has quite a bit missing before I'd throw thirty dollars at my computer screen.   Don't get me wrong about the not recommended, but again, it feels like it's more wanting than a thirsty boy who just went home with blue balls. Let's start with the biggest issue. Lag.  I guess we can blame my video card for this, but when I see my teammates go down to something similar with exclamations of, 'What the hell is hitting me?!' there isn't something right going on. I ended up bleeding out in a room after I was left behind grabbing some supplies because I started to get savaged by an invisible rat. Either that, or the inevitable plague has come.  Best thing about this game now. The characters. Not just because their personalities are good and they actually interact and talk with each other, but their unique fighting styles bring their own touch to any encounter. It's too bad there's only four though, and one has to awkwardly stand on the sideline wondering if the solution to all this is one giant glue trap with a gallon of peanut butter. Though, some extra people would be nice!  One of the other things that bugs me. I know, curse me for not figuring this out by digging through the loot system, but ♥♥♥♥ me I had only a weekend and I had and have Total War: Warhammer to play with. Something I really enjoy, I might review later, but I digress. The problem is that the weapons are much more limited than I thought it would be, they do change up stats but not so much on the styles. I figured this out because ♥♥♥♥ing hell I will NOT sit through repeating the same levels to gamble on a dice system to figure out the weapon variety is lacking. Left 4 Dead did start this off with tier 1 then tier 2 weapons to be laid out for use. Then Left 4 Dead 2 with random weapons through the environment...  But I did enjoy the selection of equipment before each mission. Like picking out a pretty dress for prom night. Except with more vermin, gunfire, and blood. ... Mostly just more vermin.  Speaking of prom nights, it shows that there were only a few missions you can do and survival mode. Left 4 Dead had a few missions, but the thing is that they didn't wear on you quickly because they were in stages, using safe rooms to be the goal and the chance for the game to load the next of your debilitating gauntlet.  Honestly, this review was because I was bored and sleepy. While my points are thought through with my awake and concentrated mind, I guess this isn't quite as humorous as the usual. There's only so many jokes you can squeeze out of giant rat men. That's what I spent most of highschool doing.        HA.

EDIT: The crashes and progress bugs appear to have been resolved, based on my last 5 hours of play. The host issues remain, so I still cannot change the reccommended status on this review. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------  This game is entertaining, but sadly suffers from numerous problems, many which just carried over from Beta without being addressed. Fatally, crashes upon launch and during play are common, with progress breaking bugs happening with frequency also. Being that you receive loot at the end of each run, this is especially irritating.   Furthermore, when the host drops, the instance is reset and all progress is lost. Why not just have another party members resume host and continue the instance? Either this or a crash has stopped me from finishing a run at least 10 times in as many hours of play, and nullified each run.  On top of this, after just 10 hours the game is already getting very repetitive. There are only 5 regular enemies to fight, with most of them just being standard melee enemies who run at you and do the same charged attack. Minor issues for me include the extremly slow acquisition of gear (subjective as to whether this is good or not), lack of weapon reloading animations (cmon just making the gun dissapear below view is not up to scratch for 2015), sloppy AI pathing and movement, and somewhat basic movesets. Most melee fighting comes down to spamming left click to hit the rats before they land their charge attack, (they are either 1 shotted or stunned, so it defeats the purpose of using other tactics in most cases) and if they pile up the occasional sweep attack or push back. The epitome here for developer laziness is the fact that you cannot turn off music or alter individual audio levels. If I want to play some music as I grind away, I have to mute the entire sound for the game. What year are we in again?  Coming from other melee games like Chivalry, or other multiplayer coop shooters like Killing Floor 2, it feels lazy, and like a major step backwards. You'll get fun out of this game, but in my opinion it's one to pick up on sale, 50% or less.

I love this game and even though it's similar to Left 4 Dead (which I love equally), it's not necessarily a bad thing to bring a familiar element from one game to another before introducing new ideas. It's a nice way to ease a player in, instead of risking to lose people due to there being more than they are willing to learn/handle. While some people love games with groundbreaking new ideas that create their own identities, I think this establishes it's own spot while being something someone can pick up to play with friends who know nothing about it firsthand The fact that they can identify that it's similar to Left 4 Dead allows them to immediately adopt the core play style they are familiar with to be able to get through a majority of the game and enjoy it on that premise alone. From there on they can discover the things that are new and different like aspects enemies have and the pros and cons of different charms with their abilities, stamina management used between blocking and shoving, letting the caster cooldown or risk exploding because you need 1 more spell to save someone, weapon types, weapons with unique attributes gotten through drops, a crafting mechanic, a loot system and a way to make the game harder without raising the difficulty as a whole that rewards you (in a sense, probability can still screw you on a dice roll) if you can make it to the end(bonus dice, tomes and grimoires). I find one of the things this game does even better than left for dead is making the party stick together to maximize teamplay elements. The primary means of disposing enemies are melee weapons. They give you ranged weapons but they teach you to ration ammo which is generally on a much shorter supply (cooldown for the caster) due to the unique enemy types because it's better in most cases (although not impossible/doable) to kill those guys from afar while horde fodder is much more easily handled with melee. With Left 4 Dead I find people mowing through enemies and rolling past hordes because they can and doesn't really force people to think as much. Guns are everywhere and ammo is bountiful, people get screwed over more by people who HAVE to speedrun EVERYTHING and get the group separated or more so by the environment (death charges, tight spaces, etc) with the exception of a well coordinated infected attack (a feature not in Vermintide yet due to no vs but we may get there). Melee combined with the horde spawns keep you together where as in Left 4 Dead 2, it was more of a neat bonus. You only really used it if anything got close enough to you, were good enough to get the smokers tongue or were hopped up on adrenaline. Different paths can have different means of getting to places based on map memory and can help in avoiding confrontations and lead to potential items for current or end based gain (rolls). It invokes more communication between players imho. While I will praise this game for what it has offered, the only things (apart from no vs mode yet) I will admit to not being a fan of two things: no chapters/checkpoints on the maps and the rng loot dice rolls. It's all one long run and if you fail, you start from square one on the map or start a different level altogether. It makes the game REALLY hard to enjoy as much when you get so far or get a lot of bonus dice like items to see it all go down the drain when/if you die and even if you do make it, sometimes even with all the bonus dice you can get to boost your chances at good items, get boned because rng hates you like 50% of the time but it feels like 100% of the time and even with the level up bonus loot you get, it dosen't get good until a certain level point which turns the game into that much more of a grind unless you are having a real good time with friends and don't really care all that much in the end. Are the games similar? Certainly. Are they the same? No. It's harder for youtuber groups like these to really find that out because a lot of the time, they record their first time playing or don't bother to play/learn before hand because a lot of this is the fun of getting to play with friends and a lot of attention is more found going in that direction. All we can hope is that enough of what is made an obvious difference between the two is enough to encourage these groups to explore further, play more, and fully enjoy the games full potential while still enjoying the similar essence of what Left 4 Dead 2 gave it

Intial Review: This game is very fun to play with 4 people. I have been able to get alot of the people who use to be big on l4d1 and l4d2 into a game which has good replay value and the same underlying concept of utilizing team work to get a know acomplishment. I would give this an 8 out of 10. Due to a few things needing to be polished, or lack what I would consider a great game.  Positive: There are many maps around (15 I think) which you can play, which is a lot more than the orginal 5 maps l4d orginally offered. There is a wide variaty of styles and combat choices that each individual player can play. There are 5 various levels of game play averaging from easy to nightmare mode. There is an upgrade system for weapons. There is a good variaty of enemys to play against espically against you storm vermin....... It also offers another higher risk vs reward where you can collect tombs (which take hp spots) to grimoires which lowers your overall teams hp to get better dice rolls for weapons and other trinkets. This game constantly keeps the player on the move, unlike in l4d where there were slow parts with no zombies or very little.  Negatives: There are still many bugs and glitchs espcially for special vermin. The pack master and vermin runner (hunter) are by far the most glitchy. From teleporting across openings, to having bad hit boxes, to not having shoving not affect them or your fellow ally. There is a drop system and basically to get good drops you as a player will have to grind on specific levels getting grimoires and tombs for the ones that do have them. This will also encourge people to utilitze glitches to get past harder parts of those levels which offer grimoires in the game. The levels that dont offer this, well there is not much reward in itself other than beating a level to get the final experience and open more levels (you can still get a chance of getting a drop, its just must lower without tombs and grimoires). The drop system is also very noticable in weapon damage, for example one of the characters I like to play I only have grey items (lowest level) it takes about 2-3 hits to kill (not a headshot) 1 average rat. Yet when I play with others who have golden level items they will kill the same enemy in 1 hit (not including head shots). Enemys seem to spawn ontop of players more than one occasion and sadly that can be a pack of storm vermin which insta kill you or even a rat ogre.... yes I have had both spawn ontop of me.....it ended badly.  Final: Overall this game is very fun despite the very apparent glitches and screwed up special vermin. If some of the items listed in the negatives area be improved I think the game will do very well. Espeically not having tombs, or grimoires on all levels. As long as FatSHark provides good support and timely fixes i think this game will be high up on those who enjoyed l4d's list (I just hope Fatshark doesnt make the same mistake that TRS did with evolve). This game provides alot of potentinal just as evolve did on intial release, but because of the lack of support of inherent glitches, and imbalances in the game is one of the main reasons why most later on gamers who stuck to higher levels of playing shyed away from the game.

The game is still graciously fun and definitely a game for those who enjoyed L4D that is in combination with a gearing system.  Do I recommend this game? Yes. Is it for everyone? No. Is it for those who need a game that has a lot of grinding, RNG, and has end-game? Yes.  Edit: Similar to Diablo 3, I think I'll be investing at least 500 hours into this game. I am a true believer that D3 was an amazing game in the sense of the gearing, variation of builds, newly introduced sets, an insane goal that is set for the future (Grift 100), and, of course, a ♥♥♥♥ ton of RNG.

Played this game a few times and enjoyed it a lot. If you liked the Left 4 Dead games or even co-op survival games, then this one is for you. You pick from a few different classes and go out as a group to each level, completing mini-objectives until you reach the end and escape. You can also level up your characters, even switching between them before each level, and equip them with better gear that you gain through levels and loot. Not something that I can play for too long without getting tired out, but its definitely fun to play once or twice a day if you have the time.

For anyone who misses L4D, don't read this, buy the game.  It plays very similar: 4 player co-op, special Skaven with similar abilities as the infected attempting to disrupt your positioning, health and special items scattered around randomly to help you carry on.  In combat, it's much more melee-centric. Ammunition is limited, and many classes are built with stronger melee in mind, so their ranged choices are for dealing with special Skaven quickly, and less effective against the hordes. Waywatcher, Witch Hunter, and Bright Wizard have weapons that can make crowd control easier. The specialization of each character improves on the L4D model by not giving everyone the same vulnerabilities and dependant on the same strategies for survival.  I've yet to play all the missions available, yet, but there appears to be more campaigns than L4D + L4D2 + DLC combined. In addition, there's a simple loot and reward system that takes mere moments to manage between missions, and in most cases, you'll directly go to another mission rather than waste time not earning loot for upgrades.  I've been playing near-nonstop since release, and yet to feel like it's becoming repetative, despite only having played 1 of the 5 characters.

The game frequently crashes (every 10 minutes) and the devs told me they can't or won't fix it. I reported this crash in pre-purchase Beta. I can't even complete a mission because the game crashes.  Dev: 'If you get this error it means the operating system detected that your GPU have been unresponsive for more then 2 seconds and decides to shut down the graphics driver. The exact cause is at this moment unknown, and unfortunately it leans towards this being a software/hardware/driver issue that is somehow triggered more frequently when running Vermintide.' Steam won't even refund me because I played the one level that doesn't crash a couple times thinking the devs would fix this.

UPDATE: Fatshark dev has commented about some of these issues and it seems they are rapidly being fixed. That's a good enough sign for me to finally recommend the game. GJ fatshark!  I had to make sure this wasn't early access before writing this. This game is VERY buggy. But it is fun... It just needs some serious bug fixes. If you're OK with the hassle, it might be worthwhile. If you get frustrated by constant bugs that interfere with gameplay and progression, give it a few patches.  Here's what I think is wrong with the game:  1) PUSH TO TALK IS DISABLED BY DEFAULT. WHAT. THE. ♥♥♥♥. Not just your own voice, but you can't hear others either!! Make sure you turn this on IMMEDIATELY. Every game there's someone who can't hear the rest of the team and we have to type. This isn't the kind of game where you can stop to type.  2) Tabbing out of the game, especially when loading, can cause your cursor to stick in first person mode. If you have two monitors, it will let you click the other monitor, tabbing you out of the game. This means you can't turn to the right. Fixed by opening your inventory, which you can only do at the start of the map.  3) It's crashed several times so far. Any progress is lost. Your player slot is pretty much instantly filled, which sucks if you were playing with a friend.  4) If the host leaves, you restart the level. This happens more frequently, especially on hard difficulty if the host doesn't get their way.  5) Hook rats can pull allies through some walls. If this happens, you can't save the ally.  6) The hunter rats very often tackle a player and fly up 200 feet in the air. They come back down, but it's a ton of free damage from the duration of the jump. It's also just stupid nonense, they jump straight up into the air all glitchily.  7) There's a LOT of ledges that are maybe 2 inches tall, but you get hung up on them. Some of them are in really obvious places that you have to pass.  8) You have to watch 4-5 unskippable cutscenes every time you open the game. Even if you were just changing graphic settings or if you had just crashed. 'It's unskippable because it's loading' they say. No it isn't. I've got this game on an SSD, it loads in a few seconds.  9) The items you get for levelling seem to be random. The first few levels I got repeats of the starter gear. Incredibly stupid when you're excited to get some new types of weapons.

'The tide rises, and finds me ready' -Bardin Goreksson  Picture this: you and three friends must run, hack, and blast your way across a city overrun with foul creatures clamouring for your blood. Sound familiar?  Perhaps the most fully realised on-screen recreation of the Warhammer Fantasy universe yet made, Vermintide excels in its world building, bringing to the table a combination of excellent hack 'n slash action (Fatshark does first-person melee combat like no-one else), a selection of varied, finely balanced levels, and a meticulous attention to character and environment design. It's also a shameless homage to the Left 4 Dead series, taking most of its key game mechanics from Valve's co-op zombie survival franchise. That's not a bad thing though, and there is still much to differentiate Vermintide from L4D, most notably it's distinct yet flexibly customisable classes and its loot/levelling/crafting systems. And that's without mentioning the wonderfully evil rat-men themselves. Fatshark has gone to town creating your Skaven foes: They hiss threats from the shadows, rise up from the gutters behind you in ambush, madly rush you in massive numbers or cower in fear when alone. To say that the Skaven are the real stars of this game would not be an overstatement.  But while Vermintide improves on L4D in many ways, in others it still lags behind: the devs have gone to great efforts in crafting memorable characters and locations, but have completely failed to present a unified story like the one in L4D 2. You're supposed to be part of the 'resistance' against the Skaven occupation, but in reality the game doesn't tell any story about this resistance outside of the isolated action snapshots of the missions, with the final encounter being particularly anti-climactic. In addition, the game suffers from some horrifically long loading screens and the occasional frustrating server issue. That said, this is an otherwise excellent experience, with much to like. Certainly worth your time and money.
Great game!

A very fun game......as long as you play with friends.  The AI bots attack about 30% as fast as a player, and that's if/when they decide to attack. They also prioritize killing enemies to rescuing teammates and even if they have your rescue meter at 90%, if an enemy comes into range, they will drop you to go attack it. Some of the worst AI I've ever seen.  That said, get a team of players together (preferably 3-4 to limit the AI stupidity), and it's a whole load of fun.  The game is very difficult, even on Easy difficulty, making losing the relatively long missions frustrating at times.  The loot system is.....interesting. You unlock items through levelling up and also through completing missions, but the mission loots aren't limited to the character you're playing or to items you haven't yet unlocked, so you'll end up with a lot of items you may never use. That said, it has Upgrading, Combining, and Salvaging to help mitigate uselessness to an extent.  Despite its flaws, it's a beautiful, fun game that's a great to play with friends.

If you like L4D and killing rats, you might like this game.

Edit/Update: Let me update the bit about the bots. They aren't just hit or miss, they're horrendous. Consider this game to be borderline unplayable without friends, because the bots are that bad right now. :\ They will not use healing items, on themselves nor on you, except seemingly at random. They cannot pick up optional bonus items (tomes/etc.), and, worst of all.. On the first map you'll hit a few spots with armored rats.. which will destroy all three of your bots without difficulty every time. You have to utterly babysit that part or be ruined.. and unless you finish a level you can't get loot, soo... The bots need serious work.  The 'yes' or 'no' ness of this game is gonna depend on your preference.  The game hinges, quite heavily, on the multiplayer appeal. On your own I imagine it could still be fun, but you'll be at the mercy of hit-or-miss bots. Sometimes they pop over just in time to save you, other times they're playing leap frog over barrel as you die. Not too unusual for bots!  The game itself, unfortunately, may be a lot more 'shallow' than one would expect. Given the Warhammer Universe and all that there is to draw from I presumed, wrongly, that each character would have a bit more 'depth' to them. This may or may not be a deal breaker for you. The only difference in characters is the weapons they can use, and some are pretty similar. There's no progression in terms of skills, passives, or other abilities in any way, shape, or form. I was expecting at least something Borderlands-esque if not more, again just from how varied and broad the Warhammer universe is! There's plenty of items, passives, racial/army traits, and other lore that could be drawn from to give some neat flavor to the characters, rather than just 'this guy uses two swords/daggers/one sword, that guy uses a sword and shield, bigger sword, big mace' and that's really it. I was honestly very disheartened at first by that aspect and felt they had so much room to do so much more with this aspect of the characters.   Also, you only get one of each character in each map, so if you like X character and your friend likes X character.. too bad.  That said, you do start to get items with various passives, though it's entirely pure luck and optional challenge-type mission-based goals to get it, so you may just kinda get the short-end on that. Loot is tough to come by and you may just kinda be stuck 'farming' the first level or so with frustratingly awful bots. It's up to you if items with passives are interesting enough to warrant serious playtime.  With that said, the levels also seem to be static - this is maybe my second biggest complaint. I had thought maybe the goals would move around, but they do not seem to, at least not on the first few levels. This means that veteran players will have a distinct advantage and, unfortunately, any new player is going to be a weight on the team. The longer you stand aroudn the more rats come your way, they seem to spawn endlessly, so exploring or being lost is punished quite a bit.  I also have to complain a tad about the lighting - it's WAY too contrast heavy! You can go from seeing brightly illuminated clouds in the sky in front of a moon that looks like a sun, then turn and not be able to make out the textures on a barrel because it's slightly in the shadow of a building. There's not nearly enough ambiant light and the lighting feels super stark as a result.  BUT with all that said, the combat is fairly satisfying. It's a bit confusing at times - some creatures you'll drop 20 arrows in and they won't flinch, other times you'll do 5 and they'll drop without seemingly any headshots, so it's a bit hard to really read what is going on.  The melee is what really shines, though that does have a bit of quirkiness. The graphics are solid, save the lighting nuance that bugs me, and that may just be a personal thing to be fair.  I wish the levels were a bit less linear so that it required some 'figuring out' each time, but you'll get down an ideal path pretty quick, know exactly where all the bonuses are, and that sorta farts on the replayability in terms of being interesting. But, again, the combat itself is fairly satisfying.   So, if you think $30 is a good price for some reasonably satisfying first person smashing, and aren't too sour at being stuck in YET ANOTHER Warhammer game as playing nothing but the lame races, and you can deal with the relative lack of super interesting progression, then it probably is the game for you. If you have a few friends who are in the same boat, it makes it a lot better as with any sort of game of this nature. The multiplayer makes it plenty more interesting as usual.  Another note, though, you CANNOT trade. If you get a super cool item your friend would love to have.. too bad. :( Also, keep in mind this game is SERVER BASED. There appears to be NO Offline mode whatsoever. No LAN. So if the servers go up in flames or the company bails out in a year or two, you're stuck with yet another abandoned unplayable game that has no support. So.. that may be a buyer beware for some people. It's becoming more a trend in recent years and it's frightful how easy we can all be left holding the bag.  It's kinda annoying when I just wanna hop on alone and mess around by mself but can't due to some server nonsense.

I gotta be honest, although there are few things that could use some tinkering. This game is an absolute blast to play with your friends.  + Decent graphics. + Artstyle stays true to Warhammer in every respect. + It's a Left 4 Dead type of game, why aren't there more clones of it? No idea. + Skaven > Orcs > Chaos + Highly replayable. + Beta only has 3 levels and is still entertaining for several hours even without replaying all that much. + 5 classes with different abilities, customization options and loot. + You get randomized loot at the end of each level, which is an awesome mechanic for a game like this.  - While graphics are decent, the optimization is not. Hopefully they have fixed this at release. - Bugs out every now and then, one could say it's still a beta but regardless. Bugs. - Objectives in each level can sometimes be a bit too linear and just feature running from point A. to point B. Although this might change up with the fully released product and the 10 maps we haven't seen yet.  Can't really think of anything else right now. Overall i would recommend this game, although you probably should wait until it has been released.

A challenging and fulfilling Left 4 Dead style game in the Warhammer universe.  Did you hate Left 4 Dead? *BETA review  Too me Warhammer: End Times- Vermintide is a amazing game so far, With it being released today I think that it will only become better. The combat system in the game is surprisingly good for a horde type game. The sword play is really good every hit you deliver onto a rat is satisfying (especially cutting there heads off) the game modes are all objective so far, but what makes the play style unique everytime is like Left 4 Dead's random spawning where it spawns random rats instead of say a Orgre Rat at one place every playthrough its just random. One of my favorite things is the loot system as of now you don't find loot in game but after the game if you are successful you gain dice you can roll some dice are rarer than others and have a higher chance of getting a better rarer item. The classes are really fun there is not one I can't play there are 5 of them. I also love the forge you can unlock special abilities for your weapons via the forge. The only thing I have too complain about is the optimization but since its beta it should be worked out. Buy it if you like pounding rat faces in ;)

Even with it still getting worked on, it came out for only 30$ (40$ for special). First DLC is also free so thats a bonus. PAy DLC is also on its way but its easier to invest in a game when it comes out cheap.  I think big developers need to follow these guys example.
