Vermintide - Hordemode done right!  Well, I personally enjoy the game a great deal even in it's unoptimized, content lacking and repetitive state. I guess the repetitiveness is kinda-sorta tied to this genre. However, I totally feel like the crafting and therefore character customization act as a hard counter to that 'problem'.  For example, I wasn't able to enjoy L4D 1 and/or 2 even closely as much as I do Vermintide, simply because of the lacking sense of progression. Vermintide gives you something to progress with: Loot, EXP, customization --> addiction.  The gameplay is impressively fluid and responsive, the hitboxes are from time to time a bit off, but mostly feel just right and reward every hit/shot with a proper, gory and satisfying animation.  The sheer amount of potential for this title is amazing, even though i highly doubt, that most of my desires won't ever come true. Some exaples, which i persoanlly think would benefit the game greatly:  - An experience based Skillsystem for each of the Heroes - A deeper Crafting-System / Loot-System - Bossmonsters (Not talking about the specials) - Maybe for the end of each chapter - Perhaps bossfight mechanics which require more than just hitting the thing untill it dies  Bottom Line: Out of all games which roam this genre, i've gotto admit:  Vermitide does it the best way. Clever, modern, addicting. Get it.

Great game. Everyone compares it to Left 4 Dead 2, and you can't really blame them. It's a horde game.   What keeps me playing (and will keep me playing for a while) are clean melee mechanics, interesting objectives during missions, pacing, and focus on teamplay.   The risk vs. reward system implemented in the way you get loot is interesting, and while many people question it, I support it. To get to roll on the loot table, you MUST be victorious in the mission. I think this forces more people to play the game 'properly' for their own benefit. It encourages teamplay. Of course, it does open the doors for trolls, but thus far, I've yet to experience one, and I only play pubs.  Also, you can pick up items to boost the number of dice you get to roll on the loot table. These items take up useful slots, like your engineer slot for Grimiores, or your Health potion slot for Tomes. (both of which reward extra dice). This adds an extra risk vs reward scenario that each player must consider during the course of the game (usually).  I find myself balancing melee with ranged as all of the characters. This is interesting because in most games, you tend to focus more on one or the other.   The loot is upgradable, none of it is really overpowered... they found a way to balance things just right, it seems.   Great game. I definitely recommend picking it up. It's worth full price, and definitely worth sale prices. Enjoy!

Intial Review: This game is very fun to play with 4 people. I have been able to get alot of the people who use to be big on l4d1 and l4d2 into a game which has good replay value and the same underlying concept of utilizing team work to get a know acomplishment. I would give this an 8 out of 10. Due to a few things needing to be polished, or lack what I would consider a great game.  Positive: There are many maps around (15 I think) which you can play, which is a lot more than the orginal 5 maps l4d orginally offered. There is a wide variaty of styles and combat choices that each individual player can play. There are 5 various levels of game play averaging from easy to nightmare mode. There is an upgrade system for weapons. There is a good variaty of enemys to play against espically against you storm vermin....... It also offers another higher risk vs reward where you can collect tombs (which take hp spots) to grimoires which lowers your overall teams hp to get better dice rolls for weapons and other trinkets. This game constantly keeps the player on the move, unlike in l4d where there were slow parts with no zombies or very little.  Negatives: There are still many bugs and glitchs espcially for special vermin. The pack master and vermin runner (hunter) are by far the most glitchy. From teleporting across openings, to having bad hit boxes, to not having shoving not affect them or your fellow ally. There is a drop system and basically to get good drops you as a player will have to grind on specific levels getting grimoires and tombs for the ones that do have them. This will also encourge people to utilitze glitches to get past harder parts of those levels which offer grimoires in the game. The levels that dont offer this, well there is not much reward in itself other than beating a level to get the final experience and open more levels (you can still get a chance of getting a drop, its just must lower without tombs and grimoires). The drop system is also very noticable in weapon damage, for example one of the characters I like to play I only have grey items (lowest level) it takes about 2-3 hits to kill (not a headshot) 1 average rat. Yet when I play with others who have golden level items they will kill the same enemy in 1 hit (not including head shots). Enemys seem to spawn ontop of players more than one occasion and sadly that can be a pack of storm vermin which insta kill you or even a rat ogre.... yes I have had both spawn ontop of me.....it ended badly.  Final: Overall this game is very fun despite the very apparent glitches and screwed up special vermin. If some of the items listed in the negatives area be improved I think the game will do very well. Espeically not having tombs, or grimoires on all levels. As long as FatSHark provides good support and timely fixes i think this game will be high up on those who enjoyed l4d's list (I just hope Fatshark doesnt make the same mistake that TRS did with evolve). This game provides alot of potentinal just as evolve did on intial release, but because of the lack of support of inherent glitches, and imbalances in the game is one of the main reasons why most later on gamers who stuck to higher levels of playing shyed away from the game.

Pros: Graphics, fun fighting, difficulty.  Cons: Glitches, Bots A.I., and replay value.  The game is very fun when you first play it. Graphics are good and gameplay is interesting and fun. Combat is challenging and strategy is important. I had high hopes for this game. Unfortunately there are some major problems. The game is very short. You could beat it in one day very easily. 12 maps total. None take more than 30 min to complete. Game is glitchy. Devs did not take the time to test it correctly. Game will crash on startup, in the middle of maps, and rats will hit you through walls. All things I would only expect in beta. I have 30 hours logged right now and that means I basically got a little more than 1 dollar per hour. Loot system is really... well bunk. You struggle your nuts off to get to the end of a map on higher difficulty and after you finally win you get an item for completing the level. But wait... the items are on a totem pole that allows you to get one notch up per die roll. 6 sided dice and one spot for loot. The odds are terrible that you will get a good item. Most likely you will get another paper weight sword or axe that you already have 10 of. I have to admit I don't understand how so many people could recommend this game in its current state. I am starting to lose faith in reviews on steam. Without an empowering loot system the replay value after completing the game is really... well non existent.  P.S. The bots are useless so if you can't find a game with human players you are screwed.

Excellent game! Even better if you have friends to play with. If you don't, like me, you can still play with bots or random players, and so far I've not had a bad experience with random players. A lot of them don't use their mic or even text chat, but they still play well and help you when you're down.  It feels like Left 4 Dead mixed with a bit of Chivalry. There's a large focus on melee, though there are pistols, rifles, crossbows, etc. for when you need to kill someone from a distance.  The game is very fleshed out, with a loot system (roll dice after finishing a mission, you get more dice to roll by completing higher difficulties, collecting hidden tomes and grimoire in the missions, etc.) and a forging system. You can combine 5 items of the same rarity level to create a new item. It's very addicting!  There's an Inn that you can hang out at between missions if you want to. You can look at your inventory here, mess with the forging system, vote on the next mission, and test out your weapons.  There's five classes to play as. Witch Hunter, Bright Wizard, Dwarf Ranger, Empire Soldier, and the Waywatcher. They all feel very different from one another and a cool touch is that they all have voices and will respond to one another during missions.  I'd highly recommend this game, it's a fantastic co-op game with a lot of depth. There may only be 11 missions, but each one has a bit of randomization to it and feels fresh each time you play through it.

Update: Since writing this review, I am pleased to say that Fatshark have done outstanding work on the networking and stability issues I highlighted. The game is now incredibly stable, and I've had no issues at all since launch. In spite of my skepticism that a week's beta time would be enough to smooth out these problems, Fatshark have actually done it. Kudos to them, and two thumbs up for an excellent game. Whole-heartedly recommended.  My original review follows below.  -----  The game itself is fantastic; an updated Left 4 Dead with some fun new mechanics, that makes superb use of the Warhammer IP (if you're a fan and concerned that this is going to be another of the myriad shovelware cash-ins coming out right now, don't be; I haven't seen the Warhammer world depicted so perfectly since Dawn of War). I'm also a big fan of the way it picks up on Left 4 Dead's trick of storytelling without breaking up gameplay, and the banter between the characters is genuinely brilliant, moreso because you'll only ever have 4 of the 5 on a mission, so you get to pick up different conversations each time. The weapon and load out choices add a whole extra layer of replayability, and there's more than enough variety to let each player find something they like. The missions themselves are fun, albeit repetitive, and the game will definitely need a few injections of content to keep it entertaining. On the other hand, the developers seem to be planning lots of extra levels and characters, so I could definitely see myself putting plenty of time into this, and at a $30 price tag it can get away with being a little lighter on content than some other titles.  So why don't I reccomend it? Because the game isn't ready for launch, plain and simple. It's brilliant, and cracking good fun, but the networking issues and frequent crashes (and the fact that a host crashing ends the entire session) make the game barely playable. Fatshark need to get these problems figured out if they want this game to survive its first four weeks, and I seriously doubt that 5 days is enough time for them to do that. Another four weeks in beta would have been ideal.  I'm hoping these issues will get fixed, and if they do I'll glad change my review.

Vermintide is at once incredible evidence of the lasting potency of the Left 4 Dead formula, and tragic evidence of just how much randomized loot systems can ruin everything. In spite of an over-emphasis on spammy first-person melee combat, Vermintide has all the right structure, customization, procedural elements and risk/reward options to make for an enduring source of adventure. Unfortunately, the persistent customization options are themselves tied to an incredibly random, time-consuming, all-encompassing, unrewarding and brutally chore-like loot system.

I'm absolutely TORN on how I feel about this game. Combat feels workable, the core gameplay loop is great and there's actually a degree of depth in this game. At a glance it appears as a completely blatent knock-off of Left 4 Dead's model, and while it is very much *inspired* by the model to the point of replication the developers added in some new features that make it stand out and seem unique. Despite this there are quite a few issues with how the developers intended to make gameplay 'last longer' utilizing a leveling/EXP system, a loot drop system at the end of each level based on rolling digital dice, and an infuriatingly poorly implimented 'crafting' system that was recently added (just before I began playing).  The good bits: I love the Skaven as an enemy type. They've got visual designs that appear interesting and are just so fun to tangle in a melee with. From the heavily armored Storm Vermin (who can come in patrols that can easily wipe underprepared teams), to the Bombadier Rat who lobs gas bombs at you, to the very sleek design of the Assassin Rat, every rat save for the notible exception of the Rat Ogre (literally a rat version of the Tank from left 4 dead in literally every way) looks absolutely fantastic. Combat feels visceral yet rewarding, with weapons acting somewhat well and a clear tradeoff between vicious attack speed and much-needed armor penetration for dealing with all of the scarier threats in the game. This game has a solid gameplay loop fixed firmly in the model that Left 4 Dead began with, and if you've got a few friends to play this with, it can be absolutely fun.  The not-so good bits: Many problems with this game stem from the absolute lack of innovation on an established, but tired model built in the Left 4 Dead franchise. In addition to that, the gameplay feels a slight degree of unrefinement- especially in the Melee combat (the whole reason you play this over Left 4 Dead, unless you have a thing for molesting rats with various fantasy weapons). Generally speaking I've seen three types of successful Melee Combat- Condemned: Criminal Origins has a standard center-screen attack, a charged swipe attack, and a block. Half Life 2 and most old-style shooters use a standard 'reticle' melee attack which hits exactly where you point the mouse, with laser precision. Dead Island had a location-specific aim and swing mechanic that allowed you to make tricky headshots or hit specific limbs. To Vermintide's discredit, neither of these approaches are used. You've got a 'close enough' center screen attack, a 'probably' charged swing attack, and a block that sort of works sometimes (depending on variables that I've yet to work out the meta on besides Shields being useful and everything else sucking). The melee combat feels like it's inching close to workability but sometimes trying to get headshots on the armored foes that you absolutely need to get headshots on can feel like playing a D20 system.  The UGLY truth: This game is a time-sink which has a reward system built entirely around one simple principle - Loot Grinding. You get EXP to unlock loot, the loot is randomly generated. You complete missions to get loot, the loot is randomly rolled for and generated. You can technically play the very-hard version of the game where you pick up hidden books that take up healing and utility slots of your inventory, just to modify how screwed you are in the RNG loot system. At its very core, Vermintide is a game that has solid gameplay built entirely around this loot system. Loot is tiered, there's even 'tokens' you get from losing missions or breaking down weapons using the in-lobby forge and it's just a mess. It's a game that wants you to play it for hours, but won't let you have the power-creep that any non-grinding person will want to play. I can't tell you readily how many runs of the first mission, The Horn of Magnus, I've played loot-grinds on. I can tell you that mission is hilariously burned into my brain- when more exciting missions should be instead.  Lastly, souring my experience is that the missions are kind of slotted together without any real narrative beyond some breifings and the premise of the game. Additionally, I've yet to find a way to disable the introduction cinematic and have to wait for it to load, skip it, and then load the in game lobby. Oh yes, the lobby loads every time- simultaneously a cool menu and a poor starting room for most players (you explore the menu in first person, essentially). If it had a better narrative, a more rewarding loot system (seriously, of the 14 hours i've played thus far, probably 10 of it has been spent loot grinding for a single decent Mace and Shield combo), and a bit more consistent melee system, I'd recommend it at the full listed MSRP. However, I can only suggest to purchase it on sale for now, until the game gets more fixes and/or some content added. Oh and lets not forget that loot system SERIOUSLY needs refinement.

You'll see many comparisons to Left4Dead, and it's true for the most part. But where a lot of clones have tried and failed with a medieval/fantasy style Left4Dead co-op this game is much smoother and better built. You choose between 5 characters in a 4-player level run, wielding different weapons for each character as well as which playstyle you prefer.  The difficulty is higher than most games. Do not feel bad if you have to crank it down to easy to get the hang of it, but each succesful run feels like an accomplishment due to that. Combine that with how the game prioritizes skill over loot grinding and you have a great challenge to look forward to that's never impossible but never easy either.  Now, with the praise out of the way I'll get to the cons. The chance based rolls on items as well as their effects means you can get a very Diablo-esq feeling of loot grinding. After you beat the campaign on easy/normal, most players will tend to replay the first level or a quicker run numerous times. And while the levels differ based on what enemies spawn where, it can get repetitive very quickly. Especially if rolls don't go your way. On top of that, the overall narrative is very intriguing but sparse at best, leaving you with very little to do aside from getting better items to do more runs to get better items, etc etc etc.  All in all, the price is worth it for a single person solely because of the challenge and generally solid fun. Playing with friends however makes the whole experience exponentially better, and I would even go as far as to say don't buy it until you have a friend or friends to run this with. Simply because the game is so much better with good coordination and equally great celebration at the end.

At the time of posting this the game still has a number of minor glitches, but nothing that breaks the game for me. If the idea of smashing a Rat-Man in the face with a sledgehammer, then blasting his buddy into chunks with a blunderbuss sounds even remotely appealing to you, then you and your friends need to give this a try.

You are thrown into a world of Hack n Slash.  You become either a Wizard, Dwarf, Empire Soldier, Witch Hunter or Waywatcher. You face off rat ogres, rats, exploding rats, ugly rats, armored rats and rats with.. muscle who carry a big machine guns! You fight in sewers, magical towers, castles, towns, cities and forests!  You fight with swords, magic fire staff, pistols, shotguns, bows and arrows.  You collect magical tomes and cursed tomes that ... I guess the characters like reading books.   This co-op game is fun and will push you to your limits. (Take note of your surroundings!)  Some issues that people talk about:  Loot  Difficulty / Checkpoint Finding players  Loot:  In my 87 hours of gameplay, I have received more than enough 'exotic' weapons to equip all 5 characters.  My first game - which was Horn of Magnus (Hard) - I obtained a 'rare' weapon.  With the addition of the free DLC, obtaining exotic items became much easier. (Can't wait for the trait changes)   There is no problem with the loot system, it is fine as it is.  Please remember this game is about Hack N Slash. It isn't Loot N Loot more. Chil and have fun destroying vermin.   Difficulty / Checkpoint:  This game punishes people who are careless. The higher the difficulty, the harder it gets.  You need to take note of your surroundings and be prepared to block and dodge. Each time you move up a difficulty level, you learn something new!   Checkpoints will make this game far too easy.  If you are on your guard, you should do fine. - Watch your back, watch your teammates' back.   Finding Players: Press 'L'.  This allows you to browse all the games, I have never had an issue finding a game before.  I also meant a few wonderful people in other countries. - Met someone from the Netherlands and I am from Canada.  Public Groups are also popping up, this meant be a good way to meet people!  Having awful players: Everyone has to start somewhere. You don't become 'pro' at this game overnight.   Hope you enjoy this review!

This game is the ♥♥♥♥, great hack and slash gameplay that still manages to be replayable over and over! (TL;DR: Good gameplay, you can make you're job harder for better loot, game A.I has a mind of it's own, follow's lore(you nerds). Recommended.) Three hour's in and it's going pretty good. At first I thought it was simply something like Left 4 Dead but in the End Times but I soon discovered that wasn't the case. Loot drop's that give unique weapons with each weapon having different statistic's for each one so no two weapons are the same. To get an increased chance at better loot specific item's, Tome's and Grimoire's, with Tome's taking the health item slot and the Grimoire taking up the potion slot and reducing health around 25% per Grimoire. That coupled the game having a game director to make thing's suspiciously easy before throwing a rat ogre at you or sending horde after horde of skaven in a short span of time. All in all, it's pretty good and follow's the Warhammer lore well.

As mentioned in most reviews, this game is a lot like Left 4 dead which was a favorite game of mine. I love this style of cooperative game play where you are forced to rely on your teammates...or else you die. I was mostly pulled in by my love for Warhammer fantasy though and they definitely got that part right. Graphically the game is great, especially Drachenfels dlc, and there are some awesome looking weapons. So all that said:  The Good:   -Coop that demands teamwork or you fail.   -Nice weapon variety with lots to choose from, even though some are a bit underpowered.   -Lots of variety of levels to play and some are quite large and fun to explore and look amazing.   -This game can be very challenging and outright punishing if you choose it to be. That's a definite pro in my book.   -To expand on previous point, you can collect tomes which take up health slots, and grimoires which reduce whole  party's health. This is added optional challenge which rewards you with better chances at loot rolls.   -A loot system which gives you added incentive to keep playing.   -The combat is fun as hell! I never knew it could be so deeply satisfying to kill Rat men.   -The Rat AI is pretty good and does a great job at keeping the pressure on you at all times. I very much enjoy the rushes that come at random. I also love the randomness of mob spawns. It makes levels have a lot of replayability.   - Very dark and gritty feel to the game which is right up my alley.   -The Soundtrack is bad ♥♥♥ and totally fits Warhammer Fantasy.   The Not so good -   -Loot system has flaws - Namely It's completely RNG and you don't get much for failing a mission. It can be quite demoralizing when you fight tooth and nail for upwards of a half an hour and are rewarded with a few measly green coins ( at level 30, or nothing at all at the lower levels).   - No real reason to run some of the levels. A lot of people just farm the easiest ones over and over and avoid the more difficult maps. Should be an incentive to do all maps.   -Friendly BOT AI is horrendous. They are of little to no help to you.   - Need more variety of mobs. All of the special mobs in the game are great and each do a good job of causing you and your team problems, but I wish there was a few bosses to tackle at the end of some missions or some other races to kill besides rats.   - Some weapons are borderline useless. (Shortbows i'm looking at you). There's a few weapons where there just isnt' any scenario that it would be better to take them over others.  - Game isn't fully optimized yet, graphically. I'm running it on a 1080 and I get some frame dips in parts that really shouldn't be happening. (Overall though it works fine for me)   Overall, I feel like this game is worth playing especially if you can get it on sale. There's a lot to love here despite some things needing work. Yes the loot RNG is frustrating, Yes there's some problems with some of the weapons, and yes there's some glitches that still exist. But if you look past all that, there is a diamond in the rough here. It's a great game to play with friends and to try to beat some of the harder levels and difficulties. I can't count how many celebrations erupted (and frustrations too!) from the intense missions that we were put through in the last week or so that I've been playing. It can be quite exhilarating watching your last teammate come into the wagon at the end of a mission with a massive zerg of angry rats nipping at his heels. It can also be equally thrilling or frustrating when those dice come up big and you get that orange trinket or rare helmet. Bottom line, I personally recommend this game since I'm 70 hours into it and still having as much fun with it as i had on day 1.

Fantastic game that is highly dependant on sticking together and co-operating. Despite it's high similarity to Left 4 Dead, Vermintide brings refreshing new things to the table such as a setting that is more melee based than ranged and a loot system. The higher difficulties and extra objectives in the game can really make it a challenge for even the most seasoned of players. The gametime you will get out of this game is highly dependant on you as a player, as just like Left 4 Dead it has a limited amount of maps so after a while you will be doing re-runs of the maps. However with the new 'Quest' feature it will reward you for doing so. So far the DLC released for this game has been very statisfactory for the pricetag aswell, adding new weapons, maps and modes and i hope they will continue doing so in the future!  All in all i would highly recommend Vermintide especially for people who really liked Left 4 Dead and other very co-operation based games.

Vermintide is 4 player co-op, very much like Left 4 Dead 1&2 but in the Warhammer universe when the world is ending and the Ratlings are rising to destroy everything. It takes every positive aspect of the L4D series and expands on it with a decent story, some RPG elements and MUCH better melee. It even has some very cool homages to L4D.  It is an excellent game. At the time of this writing, It's been out for almost 1.5 years and the devs are still very active in updating it and adding content. All of the paid DLC only requires the 'host' to own it, anyone joing a game can join it and get the weapons from it, even if they don't own the DLC.   If you like L4D or the Warhammer uninverse or Co-Op games it's simply a 'Must own'.
